choices.text: It is also called coxa plana
Occurs more commonly in females
It is caused by interruption in the blood supply of the capital femoral epiphyses
Abduction, internal rotation and flexion of hip are restricted

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Perthes disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Occurs more commonly in females

 

Option B:

 

CLINICAL PRESENTATION OF PERTHE’S DISEASE

 

  • 4-8 years of age
  • Male > Female
  • Bilateral in 10% cases
  • Most frequent symptom is limp that is exacerbated by activity and alleviated with rest.
  • 2nd most frequent complaint is pain.
  • During the very early phase, joint is irritable, so extremes of all movements are diminished and painful.
  • Later on, most movements are full, but abduction (especially in flexion) is nearly always limited and usually internal rotation is also restricted.
  • When the hip is flexed, it may go into obligatory external rotation (Catterall’s sign) and knee points towards axilla (normally, the knee goes towards midclavicular region).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It is also called Coxa plana: This is true because coxa plana is the other name of Perthes disease which means flattening of the femoral head epiphysis, that occurs in this disease.

 

Option C. It is caused by interruption in the blood supply of the capital femoral epiphyses: This is also true. Perthes disease involves osteonecrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis due to ischemia of the femoral head. Between 4-8 years of age, femoral head depends on the lateral epiphyseal vessels for its blood supply and venous drainage whose situation in retinacula makes them susceptible to stretching and to pressure from an effusion.

 

Option D. Abduction, internal rotation and flexion of hip are restricted: This statement is also true. With the progression of the disease, abduction, flexion & internal rotation movements gets limited.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Perthes disease is more common in males than in females.

choices.text: Classifies epiphyseal injuries

Type IV classifies injury through epiphysis, physis, metaphysis
Type V is the perichondrial ring injury

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Salter Harris classification?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type V is the perichondrial ring injury

 

Option D:

 

EPIPHYSEAL INJURY

 

 

Salter-Harris classification for epiphyseal injury

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Type V of Salter-Harris classification is the stage of crush injury of the physis with a normal looking X-ray initially.

choices.text: Developmental dysplasia of hip
Perthes disease
Slipped Capital femoral epiphysis
Congenital coxa vara

questions.text: Irregular thigh folds are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Developmental dysplasia of hip

 

Option A:

 

CLINICAL DIAGNOSIS OF DDH

 

  • The thigh folds will be irregular in DDH.
  • Short limb as shown by Higher buttock folds, Galeazzi or Allis sign is lowering of knee on affected side in a lying child with hip and knees flexed.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Perthes disease: Physical examination in Perthes disease usually reveals a limping gait. The mobility of the hip is limited mainly in internal rotation and abduction. In addition, the legs may be of different length because of an adduction contracture or a collapsed epiphysis. The thigh folds appear normal.

 

Option C. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis: A child presenting with a chronic slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) will generally walk with an antalgic gait, out-toeing and some shortening of the affected limb. The child may complain of vague pain in the groin, thigh or knee.

 

Option D. Congenital coxa vara: The child presents with a painless limp resulting from Trendelenburg gait and minor limb length inequality. Easy fatigability or aching pain around the gluteal muscles may be a complaint.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Irregular thigh folds are seen in developmental dysplasia of hip (DDH) and is not associated with other pediatric hip conditions like Perthes, SCFE or coxa vara.

choices.text: 3, 5
1, 2
1, 5
1, 4

questions.text:
Risk factor(s) for Legg-calve-Perthe’s disease is/are:

 

  1. Accelerated skeletal growth
  2. Growth hormone abnormalities
  3. Positive family history
  4. Female sex
  5. Passive smoking
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3, 5

 

Option A:

 

RISK FACTORS FOR LEGG-CALVE-PERTHES DISEASE

 

  • Positive family history
  • Legg-Calve-Perthes disease occurs most commonly in male patients, with a male to female ratio between 4:1 and 5:1.
  • Most consistent factor affecting course is patient’s age at onset of disease. Younger the age, better the prognosis.
  • Outcome is also affected by duration from onset to complete resolution; the shorter the duration the better the final results.
  • Head at Risk sign in Perthes are: (these indicate poor development of femur head from femur epiphysis)
    • Lateral subluxation of the femoral head
    • Speckled calcification lateral to the capital epiphysis
    • Gage sign: a radiolucent ‘V’-shaped defect in the lateral epiphysis and adjacent metaphysis
    • Sagging Rope Sign: metaphyseal sclerotic band

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Accelerated skeletal growth. Skeletal immaturity is the aetiology in Perthes disease, which retards the bone age.
  2. Growth hormone abnormalities. Growth hormone deficiency is the another risk factor for Perthes disease.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The risk factors associated with Legg-Calve-Perthe’s disease are a positive family history & presence of passive smoking.

choices.text: Increased medial joint space
Metaphyseal cysts and rarefaction
Lateral extrusion of femur head
All of the above

questions.text: Which of the following is X-ray feature of Perthes disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

HEAD AT RISK SIGN IN PERTHES (these indicate poor development of femur head from femur epiphysis)

 

  • Lateral subluxation of the femoral head
  • Speckled calcification lateral to the capital epiphysis
  • Gage sign: a radiolucent ‘V’-shaped defect in the lateral epiphysis and adjacent metaphysis
  • Sagging Rope Sign: metaphyseal sclerotic band

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The X-ray features of Perthe’s disease are increased medial joint space, metaphyseal cysts & rarefaction, and lateral extrusion of the femoral head.

choices.text: Adduction and external rotation
Abduction and external rotation
Adduction and internal rotation
Abduction and internal rotation

questions.text: Which of the following movements is restricted in Perthes disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abduction and internal rotation

 

Option D:

 

CLINICAL PRESENTATION OF PERTHE’S DISEASE

 

  • During the very early phase of the disease, the joint is irritable so, extremes of all movements are diminished and painful.
  • Later on, most movements are full, but abduction (especially, flexion) is nearly always limited and usually internal rotation also.
  • When the hip is flexed, it may go into obligatory external rotation (Catterall’s sign) and knee points towards axilla (normally, the knee goes towards midclavicular region).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A, B, C. During the initial phase of the disease, only extreme of all movements are diminished & painful. Later on, most movements are full except for abduction (with flexed hip) & internal rotation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Of all the movements of the hip, only abduction & internal rotation movements are restricted.

choices.text: TB hip
CDH
Perthes disease
Slipped upper femoral epiphysis

questions.text: The commonest cause of limp in a child of seven years is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perthes disease

 

Option C:

 

  • Perthes is the most common cause of limp in age group 4-8 years.
  • Limp is exacerbated by activity and alleviated with rest.

 

DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSIS OF LIMPING CHILD

 

  • Painless Limp:
    • 1-3 Years age group:
  1. DDH (Developmental dysplasia of hip)
  2. Cerebral palsy
  3. Muscular dystrophy
  4. Infantile coxa vara
  • 4-10 Years age: Limb length discrepancy, Poliomyelitis
  • Painful Limp:
  1. Legg Calve Perthes disease (NOTE: Classically, perthes is described as painless limp)
  2. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis
  3. Osteochondritis dissecans (knee) (Lateral surface of medial femoral condyle)
  4. Arthritis/Synovitis/Osteomyelitis
  • Order of investigation in Limping Child: X-ray followed by Ultrasound followed by MRI.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. TB hip. Early presentations are pain around hip and limp. But pain is the most common complaint in TB hip patients.

 

Option B. CDH. Congenital Dysplasia of Hip occurs in children in the age group of 1-3 years and involves presentation of a painless limp. The given question mentions about a 7-year-old child, so CDH is ruled out here.

 

Option D. Slipped upper femoral epiphysis. A stable SCFE causes stiffness or pain in the knee or groin, & possibly a limp, causing the child to walk with the foot outward. The pain & limp may come & go, & may worsen with activity & get better with rest.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The commonest cause of limp in a 7-year-old child will be Perthes disease due to disrupted blood supply to the head of femur.

choices.text: High dose of calcium with steroids
Total hip replacement
Supervised containment of femoral head in acetabulum
Relieving weight bearing

questions.text: Perthes disease is treated by:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supervised containment of femoral head in acetabulum

 

Option D:

 

MANAGEMENT OF PERTHES DISEASE

 

  • The head is required to be kept inside the acetabulum while the revascularization takes place (head containment).
  • The main aim of treatment is containment of femoral head in acetabulum.
  • Nonsurgical containment is achieved by orthotic braces.
  • All braces abduct the affected hip, most allow for hip flexion, and some control rotation of the limb.
  • Broomstick or Petrie cast issued.

 

 

  • Surgical containment is through:
    1. Femoral varus derotation osteotomy
    2. Chiari osteotomy and cheilectomy (surgically removing protruding fragments of femoral head usually anterolateral)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. High dose of calcium with steroids. Calcium dose protects the infarcted femoral head from deformity but lacks bone anabolic effects. Steroids use reduces the oxygen in the blood which is required for the joint.

 

Option B. Total hip replacement. Treatment with hip replacement at a younger age puts the children at a higher risk of failure of surgery.

 

Option D. Relieving weight bearing. Weight-bearing restriction is associated with poor mobility in active stage of the disease.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The main treatment of Perthes disease is use of braces that keep the hip in abduction, flexion & some internal rotation, to contain the femoral head in the acetabulum.

choices.text: Avascular necrosis may occur
Usually occur after 10-year of age
Obesity is a risk factor
More common in girls

questions.text: All are true about Slipped capital femoral epiphysis except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) More common in girls

 

Option D:

 

ETIOLOGY OF SLIPPED CAPITAL FEMORAL EPIPHYSIS

 

  • Many of the patients are either fat and sexually immature or excessively thin and tall.
  • Endocrinopathies such as Hypothyroidism (most common)
  • Growth hormone excess caused by growth hormone deficiency conditions treated by growth hormone administration.
  • Chronic renal failure (Hyperparathyroidism)
  • Primary hyperparathyroidism
  • Pan hypopituitarism associated with intracranial tumors
  • Craniopharyngioma
  • MEN 2 B
  • Turner’s syndrome
  • Klinefelter’s syndrome
  • Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome
  • Prior pelvic irradiation
  • Many times, it presents in growth spurt

 

Pathogenesis and Pathology:

 

  • Slip occurs through hypertrophic zone of growth plate.

 

Clinical Picture:

 

  • Males are more commonly affected.
  • An adolescent child (boys 13-15 and girls 11-13), typically overweight or very thin and tall presents with pain some times and Antalgic limp, with the affected side held in a position of increased external rotation (turning out of leg).
  • Restriction of internal rotation, abduction and flexion.
  • A classical sign is tendency of thigh to rotate in to progressively more external rotation, as the affected hip is flexed called as Axis deviation (Similar to Perthes).
  • Slipping usually occurs as a series of minor events rather than a sudden, acute episode.
  • Patient with unstable acute or acute on chronic SCFE characteristically present with sudden onset of severe, fracture like pain usually as a result of a relatively minor fall or twisting injury.
  • Chondrolysis complicating SCFE presents with more continuous pain, hip held in an external rotated position at rest, with flexion contracture and global restriction of hip motion.
  • The patient usually complaint of pain throughout the arc of motion rather than just at its extremities.
  • 20% cases will have evidence of contralateral slip.
  • 60% of patients will have bilateral involvement when associated with endocrinopathies.
  • Chondrolysis (Destruction of Cartilage) and avascular necrosis are possible complications.

 

Explanation:

 

Options A. Avascular necrosis may occur. True. Avascular necrosis is a possible complication of SCFE.

 

Option B. Usually occur after 10 years of age. True. SCFE is seen in adolescent children of age more than 10 years (males = 13-15 years, females = 11-13 years).

 

Option C. Obesity is a risk factor. True. Most of the patients of SCFE are fat or overweight.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • SCFE is more commonly seen in adolescent males than females of age 13-15 years, who are fat or overweight. Avascular necrosis is the possible complication of SCFE.

choices.text: Perthes disease
Slipped capital femoral epiphyses
Observation hip
Tuberculosis hip

questions.text: An 11-year-old 70 kg child presents with limitation of abduction and internal rotation. There is tenderness in Scarpa’s triangle. On flexing the hip, the limb is externally rotated. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Slipped capital femoral epiphyses

 

Option B:

 

CLINICAL PICTURE OF SCFE

 

  • Limitation of abduction and Internal rotation
  • 4-8 years: Perthes Disease
  • 11-20 years: Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis
  • The patient presents with pain some times and Antalgic limp, with the affected side held in a position of increased external rotation, restriction of internal rotation, abduction and flexion.
  • A classical sign is the tendency of thigh to rotate in to progressively more external rotation, as the affected hip is flexed. This is called as Axis deviation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Perthes disease. Perthes disease is seen in children of 4-8 years of age, and it presents with limitation of internal rotation and abduction movements of the hip.

 

Option C. Observation hip. “Observation Hip” is a provisional diagnosis in children, characterized by limp, with or without pain in the knee, thigh and groin, and limited motion of the hip joint, which may or may not be associated with systemic reactions. Its clinical manifestations are due to synovitis of the hip and occasionally due to inflammation of the psoas muscle. The aetiology is initially unknown but may be clarified by diagnostic tests and clinical observation.

 

Option D. Tuberculosis hip. In the stage of synovitis, there is joint effusion and the affected limb is flexed, abducted, and externally rotated with an apparent lengthening. There is a restriction of terminal range of movements.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In SCFE, there is limitation of abduction & internal rotation, tenderness in Scarpa’s triangle, & external rotation of the hip in flexion. It is seen in children more than 10 years of age.

choices.text: Perthes disease
CDH
SCFE
Fracture neck femur

questions.text: Trethowan’s sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) SCFE

 

Option C:

 

INVESTIGATIONS IN SCFE

 

  • A line drawn tangential to superior femoral neck (Klein’s line) on AP view will intersect a portion of the lateral capital epiphysis normally.
  • With typical posterior displacement of capital epiphysis, this line will intersect a smaller portion of the epiphysis or not at all. This is called Trethowan’s sign.

 

 

 

Radiological diagnosis of slipped capital femoral epiphysis

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Perthes disease. In Perthes disease, when the hip is flexed, it may go into obligatory external rotation and the knee points towards axilla (normally, it goes towards midclavicular region). This is called as Catterall’s sign.

 

Option B. CDH. In unilateral cases, one leg is short as demonstrated by Galeazzi/Allis test. In bilateral cases, Klisic test & Trendeleburg test are positive.

 

Option D. Fracture neck femur. In impacted and stress fractures, there is no obvious clinical deformity seen. There is minor discomfort with active or passive hip range of motion, muscle spasms at extremes of motion, pain with percussion over greater trochanter. In displaced fractures, leg is in external rotation and abduction, with shortening of the limb.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The Trethowan sign is used to diagnose slipped capital femoral epiphysis.
  • In this sign, the line of Klein passes above the femoral head.
  • It is best seen on both AP and lateral views of the hip X-ray. 
  • On the AP view of a normal hip, the Klein line intersects a small portion of the lateral capital epiphysis.
  • In posterior displacement of the capital epiphysis, the line intersects a smaller portion of the epiphysis or does not intersect it at all. This is called as positive Trethowan sign.

choices.text: Male gender is risk factor
Limbs are in adduction, internal rotation and flexion in old children
Femur neck is retroverted
Ligamentum teres is atrophied

questions.text: Which of the following is true about DDH?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Limbs are in adduction, internal rotation and flexion in old children

 

 Option B:

 

DEVELOPMENTAL DYSPLASIA OF HIP (DDH)

 

  • DDH is failure of maintenance of femoral head due to malformations of acetabulum or femur.
  • 80% of cases of DDH occur in girls.
  • DDH is more common in first born child, oligohydramnios.
  • The crowding phenomenon is the cause of its association with torticollis and metatarsus adductus.
  • Breech presentation is another strong association factor.
  • Familial association is seen.
  • But the twin pregnancy does not increase the risk.

 

 

Displaces superolaterally

 

  • Clinical diagnosis:
    1. Abduction is limited (especially in flexion)
    2. Asymmetric thigh folds
    3. Barlow’s Test: 1st part – In position of 90° flexion of hips and knees, the hip is adducted and pushed. This will lead to dislocation of hip (but not if already dislocated).
  • Beyond 6 months, closed reduction is difficult as an inferior capsule of hip assumes hourglass shape and may prevent a successful closed reduction.
  • Hypertrophy of ligamentum teres, Pulvinar (Fibrofatty tissues), Iliopsoas, Capsular Interposition are other obstructions to closed reduction.
  • All can hinder the closed reduction, so usually in this age, open reduction is carried out.

 

 

Structures interfering with closed reduction

 

  • 18-36 months: Open reduction + femoral rotation osteotomy ± pelvic osteotomy (Femur is osteotomized and rotated after 18 months).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Male gender is risk factor. Incorrect. About 80% of the cases of DDH are seen in girls (usually first born).

 

Option C. Femur neck is retroverted. Incorrect. There is superior & lateral displacement of the femoral head with sloping, shallow acetabulum. There is femoral anteversion in DDH.

 

Option D. Ligamentum teres is atrophied. Incorrect. In DDH, ligamentum teres is thickened and elongated.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • DDH is commonly seen in female patients.
  • The limbs are in adduction, internal rotation & flexed position in older children.
  • Femoral neck is anteverted.
  • Ligamentum teres is thickened & elongated.

choices.text: Examiners thumb rests on the medial thigh
Examiners finger lie on the greater trochanter
Hips are flexed to 90 degrees and gently abducted
Jerk is given to the knee to dislocate the femur head jerk of exit

questions.text: Following is not a part of Ortolani test:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Jerk is given to the knee to dislocate the femur head jerk of exit

 

Option D:

 

CLINICAL DIAGNOSIS OF DDH

 

BAAHARLO! “DAd”, i.e. Barlow’s test – Dislocation by Adduction (DAd)”

 

  • Thus, in Barlow’s, we dislocate hip joint (Provocative test)
  • IInd part: Now, the hip is abducted and pulled. This will cause ‘clunk' indicating reduction of hip.

 

 

  • Some consider only 1st part as Barlow's test
  • Ortolani's Test: the first two alphabets O and R (Ortolani for Reduction) and for Reduction, we do abduction of hip. It is similar to 2nd part of Barlow's test.

 

 

Test for DDH

 

Explanation:

 

Options A, B, and C describes the correct steps of the Ortolani test.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In Ortolani’s Test, the hips and knees are flexed to 90-degree, then an anterior pressure is applied over the greater trochanter and the examiner gently abduct the leg with thumbs.
  • The examiner’s fingers lies over the greater trochanter & thumb rests over the medial thigh.
  • If the hip is dislocated, a distinctive clunk will be heard as the hip relocates, which makes the test positive.

choices.text: Asymmetric Thigh folds may be seen
Galleazi sign and Ortolani test may be positive
It may be bilateral
Polyhydramnios is a known risk factor

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding congenital dislocation of hip except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Polyhydramnios is known risk factor

 

Option D:

 

SCREENING CRITERIA FOR DDH

 

  • Babies with risk factors associated with DDH should receive more careful screening.
  • Risk factors include family history, breech delivery, birth position, torticollis, metatarsus adductus, oligohydramnios, talipes equino varus and genu recurvatum.
  • Since the incidence is higher in females, these factors assumes greater importance in female infants and first born Caucasians.
  • Twin pregnancy is not a risk factor.

 

CLINICAL PRESENTATION OF BILATERAL DDH

 

  • In a bilateral dislocation, the gait is described as ‘duck-like waddle' or ‘sailor's gait' and consists of an inclination to the side on which the weight is born (lurching gait on both side).
  • In unilateral cases, the child lurches towards affected side. This is known as abductor lurch or Trendelenburg gait (pelvis drops on opposite side).
  • Lordosis is particularly noticeable in bilateral cases and is often presenting complaint.
  • In bilateral cases, legs appear too short for the body, the perineal space is broadened, the trochanters are unduly prominent, and the buttocks are broad and flat.
  • In unilateral cases, one leg is short which can be demonstrated by Galeazzi/Allis test.
  • In bilateral cases, there is no asymmetry on abduction; and flexed knees are at the same level.
  • Combined abduction is limited but this is difficult to detect because the limitation is symmetrical.
  • Klisic test can recognize bilateral DDH.
  • In bilateral cases, Trendelenburg’s sign is Positive on both sides and shenton's line is broken bilaterally.
  • Compensatory genu valgum is seen.

 

Explanation:

 

Options A, B, and C are correct statements regarding congenital dislocation of the hip.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In congenital dislocation of hip, asymmetric thigh folds are seen; Galleazi sign & Ortolani test may be positive.
  • CDH/DDH can be bilateral.
  • Oligohydramnios is a known risk factor.

choices.text: Hip spica
Pavlik harness
Minerva cast
Riser's cast

questions.text: A 4-month-old child diagnosed with DDH. Cast used after closed reduction is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pavlik harness

 

TREATMENT PLAN OF DDH

 

A. Neonate and Young Child (1-6 month):

 

  • Closed reduction
  • Wide abduction and forced internal rotation must always be avoided due to fear of Avascular Necrosis of Femur head.
  • Pavlik harness after hip reduces, is treatment of choice.
  • Ilfeld-craig splint, Von-Rosen splint and Freika pillow can also be used.

 

 

Pavlik harness

 

B. 6-18 months:

 

  • Beyond 6 months, closed reduction is difficult as an inferior capsule of hip assumes hourglass shape and may prevent a successful closed reduction.
  • Hypertrophy of ligamentum teres, Pulvinar (Fibrofatty tissues), Iliopsoas, capsular Interposition are other obstructions to closed reduction.
  • All can hinder the closed reduction so, usually in this age, open reduction is carried out.

 

 

Structures interfering with closed reduction

 

C. 18-36 months: Open reduction + femoral rotation osteotomy pelvic osteotomy (Femur is osteotomized and rotated after 18 months).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hip spica. After the age of 6 months, if the Pavlik harness and closed reduction fails, then following the open reduction, hip spica cast is applied. This is valid in the age group of 6-18 months.

 

Option C. Minerva cast. The Minerva cast is used to protect an injured spine or as part of the treatment for a spinal deformity like scoliosis. It includes the trunk (sometimes extending down till the rib cage) as well as the patient's head, with openings provided for the patient's face, ears, and usually the top of the head and hair.

 

Option D. Risers cast. The Riser cast is similar to the Minerva cast, extending from the patient's hips to the neck and sometimes including part of the head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In children under the age of 6 months, with DDH, after the closed reduction, Pavlik harness is applied to keep the reduction in place

choices.text: Clunk of entry on abduction and flexion of hip
Clunk of entry on extension and adduction of hip
Click of exit on abduction and flexion of hip
Click of exit on extension and adduction of hip

questions.text: Ortolani test is positive when the examiner hears the:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clunk of entry on abduction and flexion of hip

 

Option A:

 

CLINICAL DIAGNOSIS OF DDH

 

BAAHARLO! “DAd”, i.e. Barlow’s test – Dislocation by Adduction (DAd)”

 

  • Thus, in Barlow’s, we dislocate hip joint (Provocative test)
  • IInd part: Now, the hip is abducted and pulled. This will cause ‘clunk' indicating reduction of hip.

 

 

  • Some consider only 1st part as Barlow's test
  • Ortolani's Test: the first two alphabets O and R (Ortolani for Reduction) and for Reduction, we do abduction of hip. It is similar to 2nd part of Barlow's test.

 

 

Test for DDH

 

Explanation:

 

Option B, C, and D are incorrect because the clunk is heard only when the hip is flexed and then abducted, and not in any other hip movement/position.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Ortolani’s test is used to diagnose DDH and it is done by abducting the hip in flexion and then reducing the posterior hip dislocation. When the hip is relocated at its position, a ‘clunk’ is heard, which indicates the positive sign.

choices.text: Decreases
Increases
Constant
Variable

questions.text: Alpha angle in DDH:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreases

 

Option A:

 

RADIOLOGICAL FEATURES OF DDH

 

  • Alpha and Beta angles are measured for DDH and alpha angle decreases with severity whereas beta angle increases with severity of DDH (measured on USG).
  • In DDH, on USG, Alpha angle decreases, Beta angle increases
  • Normal alpha angle is > 60° while the beta angle is < 55°
  • On X-ray, Center-Edge Angle decreases

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Alpha angle is used as a measurement in ultrasonographic assessment of DDH.
  • It is the angle formed by the lines along the bony acetabulum (roof) and ilium (vertical cortex).
  • It reflects the depth of the acetabular roof.
  • In DDH, it usually decreases (< 60°).

choices.text: 3, 4
1, 2
1, 5
2, 5

questions.text:
Traumatic dislocation of epiphyseal plate of femur occurs:

 

  1. Medially
  2. Laterally
  3. Posteriorly
  4. Rotationally
  5. Anteriorly
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 5

 

Option D:

 

FRACTURE SEPARATION OF DISTAL FEMORAL EPIPHYSIS

 

  • In childhood or adolescent equivalent of a supracondylar femur fracture, the lower femur epiphysis may be displaced.
  • Valgus force caused by blow to the lateral side of distal femur is causative.
  • Salter Harris type II or III injury with distal femoral epiphysis displaced laterally with a lateral fragment of the metaphysis.
  • Hyper-extension type injury: Distal femoral epiphysis displaced anteriorly. The triangular metaphyseal fragment and intact periosteal hinge are anterior in location.
  • Nearly 70% of femur's length is derived from the distal physis.
  • So, early arrest can present a major problem.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Traumatic dislocation of the epiphyseal plate of femur occurs in anterior and lateral direction.

choices.text: Varus
Valgus
Flexion
Hyperextension

questions.text: Commonest presentation of congenital dislocation of knee is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperextension

 

Option D:

 

  • The patient presents with hyperextension deformity of the knee.

 

CONGENITAL DISLOCATION OF KNEE

 

  • Etiology and Pathology:
    • Abnormal fetal position, i.e. feet become locked beneath the mandible or the axilla causing hyperextension of knees.
    • Proximal end of tibia is displaced anteriorly and laterally on femur.
    • Congenital absence of cruciate ligament and fibrosis of quadriceps and fascia lata is seen.
    • Patella is small or absent and has fibrous adhesion to the femur.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Congenital hyperextension (genu recurvatum) is the most common presentation.
    • Clinical appearance is alarming and has been described as “knees on backwards”.
    • In most cases, reduction of deformity is possible but the knees cannot be brought into flexion.
  • Associated Disorders:
    • Larsen's syndrome/Ehler's Danlos syndrome/Streeter's syndrome
    • Myelodysplasia
    • Arthrogryposis Multiplex Congenita
    • DDH (ipsilateral)
    • CTEV (Congenital Talipes Equino Varus)

 

 

Congenital dislocation of knee – genu recurvatum

 

  • Treatment:
    • Conservative, if it can be reduced and can achieve knee flexion up to 90 degrees.
    • Surgery if persistent dislocation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Varus. The newborns have a physiological genu varum which is highest around the age of 1 year and later as the child grows the lower limbs become straight. It may be seen in conditions like vitamin D deficiency rickets, blount’s disease, physeal injury due to trauma/infection.

 

Option B. Valgus. It is most commonly seen in children with vitamin D deficiency rickets, dysplasias, achondroplasia, physeal injuries, and tumors like osteochondroma, fibrous dysplasia.

 

Option C. Flexion. This deformity is generally seen in the knees of children with cerebral palsy and spina bifida, or limb length discrepancy.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Congenital dislocation of knee is commonly presented with hyperextension deformity of the knee i.e., genu recurvatum.

choices.text: Genu valgum
Genu varus
Coxa vara
Coxa valgus

questions.text: Characteristic of blount’s disease:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genu varus

 

Option B:

 

BLOUNT’S DISEASE

 

  • It is abnormal approximation of knees with abnormally divergent ankles.
  • It can be estimated by measuring the distance between the medial malleolus, when the knees are touching with the patella facing forwards; it is usually < 8 cm.
  • Valgus alignment of lower extremities is normal in child between 2 and 8 years of age (Known as physiological valgus and is maximum between 2 and 4 years).
  • Causes:
    1. Idiopathic (Physiological is most common)
    2. Post-traumatic (Lateral Side) Fractures of the lateral condyles of tibia or femur (arrest of growth on lateral side)
    3. Post-infection
    4. Neoplastic
    5. Metabolic bone disease Rickets (mostly renal osteodystrophy type is most likely to produce valgus as it is acquired in physiological valgus age group).
    6. Rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis of lateral compartment of knee, charcot's disease and paralytic disease are other causes seen in adults.
    7. Usually, OA causes Genu Varum and RA causes Genu Valgum.
  • Treatment:
  • After 8 Years age, correction of excessive physiological genu valgum may be indicated when there is gait disturbance, difficulty in running, knee discomfort, patellar malalignment, evidence of ligamentous instability or excessive cosmetic concern.
  • In children who have significant growth remaining (boys <12 years, girls <10 years), reversible or transient hemiepiphysiodesis by staples is done.
  • Corrective osteotomy for excessive genu valgus is appropriate when the patient present near or after skeletal maturity. It is mostly close wedge osteotomy in the distal femur.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Genu valgum. It is most commonly seen in children with vitamin D deficiency rickets, dysplasias, achondroplasia, physeal injuries, and tumors like osteochondroma, fibrous dysplasia.

 

Option C. Coxa vara. The most common cause of coxa vara is either congenital or developmental. Other common causes include metabolic bone diseases like Paget's disease, post-Perthes deformity, osteomyelitis, and post traumatic.

 

Option D. Coxa valgus. It is seen more commonly in children with cerebral palsy, and hip dislocation/subluxation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Blount’s disease/infantile tibia vara is seen in children less than 3 years of age which involves varus of tibia, hyperextension of the knee, & internal rotation of the tibia.

choices.text: Defect in posteromedial part of upper tibial epiphysis
Endocrinopathy
Recovery stage of rickets
Deformity in proximal tibia

questions.text: Blount’s diseases in a bowleg deformity occur due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Defect in posteromedial part of upper tibial epiphysis

 

Option A:

 

INFANTILE TIBIA VARA (BLOUNT’S DISEASE)

 

  • Infantile tibia vara (Blount’s disease) in which patient is <3 years old at the onset of condition (more common).
  • It is characterized by abrupt angulation just below the proximal physis, an irregular physeal line, a wedge-shaped epiphysis, and a beak-like medial metaphysis.
  • Apparent lateral subluxation of proximal tibia is often present.
  • The triad of Blount’s is Tibia vara, Genu Recurvatum (hyperextension), and internal tibial torsion (internal rotation of tibia).
  • Siffert-Kartz Sign (Postero-medial Instability of Knee is seen).
  • Metaphysio-diaphyseal angle is measured and angle more than 11 degrees require close observation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Blount’s disease in a bow-leg deformity occurs due to defect in posteromedial part of the upper tibial epiphysis.

choices.text: Distal part towards midline
Distal part away from the midline
Proximal part towards midline
Proximal part away from midline

questions.text: Varus is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Distal part towards midline

 

Option A:

 

GENU VARUM

 

  • Knees are abnormally divergent and ankles approximated.
  • Bilateral bow legs can be estimated by measuring the distance between the medial malleoli when heels are touching; it should be < 6 cm to label as Genu Varum. Normally 8 cm.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Distal part away from midline. A valgus deformity is a condition in which the bone segment distal to a joint is angled outward, that is, angled laterally, away from the body's midline. It is the opposite of varus deformity.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Varus deformity occurs when the distal part moves towards the midline.

choices.text: CDH
Congenital coxa vara
Genu valgum
External tibial torsion

questions.text: Charlie Chaplin gait is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) External tibial torsion

 

Option D:

 

TIBIAL TORSION

 

  • Internal Tibial Torsion is a common condition in children less than age 4 which typically presents with internal rotation of the tibia and an in-toeing gait.
  • As a child starts walking, their feet turn in and their legs bow out.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CDH. In congenital dysplasia of hip, the child has a Trendelenburg gait due to abductor insufficiency. The child also walks on toes in an attempt to compensate for relative shortening of the affected side.

 

Option B. Congenital coxa vara. In congenital coxa vara, the child presents with abnormal but painless gait pattern. A Trendelenburg limp is sometimes associated with unilateral coxa vara and a waddling gait is often seen when bilateral coxa vara is present.

 

Option C. Genu valgum. The children with genu valgum presents with abnormal circumduction gait.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Charlie Chaplin gait or in-toeing gait is often seen in cases of external tibial torsion.

choices.text: Orthosis is a must only during weight bearing
Orthosis is recommended during day time
Orthosis is recommended during night time
Orthosis is recommended full time

questions.text: True regarding genu varum is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Orthosis is a must only during weight bearing

 

Option A:

 

  • This answer may appear to contradict modern best practices, which recommend full-time orthotic use in pathological genu varum (like Blounts disease). 

  • However, here's a plausible explanation based on the context of the original question (older exams like JIPMER 1995 and PGI 1994):

  • Orthosis is a must only during weight bearing. This implies that mechanical load during standing and walking contributes significantly to the progression of genu varum.

  • The idea here is that, bracing is especially important when the child is bearing weight, because that's when deforming forces are greatest.

  • Hence, the orthosis must be used during weight-bearing, although it doesn't exclude using it at other times.

  • In older clinical teaching, this was often emphasized bracing to counter weight-bearing forces.

  • Orthosis must be used during weight bearing, even if additional use during rest or sleep may help.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Options B), C), and D) suggest limited or full-time orthosis, and Option D (full-time) aligns more with modern best practice. 

  • But in the older exam context, the emphasis was on corrective action during weight-bearing, hence option A was considered correct at that time.

  • Modern consensus (for comparison): Full-time orthosis (option D) is now often recommended for effective correction in early stages of pathological genu varum.

  • Still, orthosis is absolutely essential during weight bearing, so A is not technically wrong, but rather incomplete by todays standards.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Orthosis is a must only during weight bearing was considered correct in earlier exams like JIPMER 95/PGI 94, emphasizing bracing during weight-bearing stress.

  • Today, Orthosis is recommended full time would be more accurate based on current orthopedic protocols.

choices.text: Congenital vertical talus
Arthrogryposis
Holding club foot in too long corrected position
All are correct

questions.text: Rocker bottom foot is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All are correct

 

Option D:

 

ROCKER BOTTOM FOOT  

 

  • Rocker bottom foot, is a foot with a convex plantar surface, with apex of convexity at the talar head.
  • Talus is vertical, so that its head forms the most prominent part of the sole.
  • The fore foot is deviated outward and dorsally.
  • It may be produced by Congenital vertical talus (congenital convex pes valgus or teratological dorsolateral dislocation of talocalcaneonavicular joint) which may be present alone or more commonly associated with myelomeningocele, arthrogryposis, prune belly syndrome, spinal muscular atrophy, neurofibromatosis, CDH, and with trisomy 13-15 and 18.

 

 

Rocker bottom

 

 

Rocker bottom foot

 

  • Causes:
    1. Oblique/Vertical talus
    2. Improper correction of CTEV, i.e. forceful correction of equinus by dorsiflexion before adduction, varus and inversion may actually cause movement at mid tarsal joint (not at ankle joint) producing rocker bottom foot.

 

 

  • Treatment: Grice procedure is extra-articular arthrodesis of subtalar (talocalcaneal) joint, done for Congenital Vertical Talus.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Rocker bottom foot is seen in congenital vertical talus (CVT), arthrogryposis.
  • It also occurs if there is prolonged holding of the club foot in a corrected position.

choices.text: Tibialis Anterior
Tibialis Posterior
Peroneus Longus
EHL

questions.text: The following muscles cause inversion of foot except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peroneus Longus

 

Option C:

 

MUSCLES OF FOOT INVERSION

 

  • Inversion is taking great toe inwards.
  • Peroneus longus muscle makes up the lateral compartment of the lower leg along with peroneus brevis muscle.
  • It originates from the lateral condyle of tibia, head & proximal 2/3rd of lateral surface of fibula, and inserts on the lateral base of first metatarsal and medial cuneiform bone.
  • It is supplied by the peroneal nerve (L5, S1, S2)
  • It functions as the evertor of the foot and ankle, and also assists in ankle plantar flexion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tibialis Anterior, Option B. Tibialis Posterior, and Option D. EHL, all functions as foot invertors.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The peroneus longus muscle functions to evert the foot and ankle and assist in foot plantarflexion while tibialis anterior and posterior and EHL muscles works as foot invertors.

choices.text: Protrusion of cuboid bone
Lateral crease
Concavity of sole
All are correct

questions.text: Pirani scoring includes all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All are correct

 

Option D:

 

PIRANI SCORING

 

  • In Pirani scoring, 6 signs are assessed, including 3 of midfoot and 3 of hindfoot and the total score is the sum of midfoot and hindfoot contracture scores.

 

 

  • Kite’s angle: AP view talocalcaneal angle.
  • Normal value is 20-40 degrees (decreased in CTEV and may become parallel)

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In Pirani scoring, 6 signs assessed are:
    • Midfoot contracture score:
      • Medial crease
      • Curved lateral border
      • Lateral head of talus
    • Hindfoot contracture score:
      • Posterior crease
      • Empty heel
      • Rigid equinus

choices.text: Ellipsoid
Saddle
Ball and Socket
Plane

questions.text: Talocalcaneonavicular joint is which type of synovial joint?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ball and Socket

 

Option C:

 

TYPES OF JOINTS

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Talocalcaneonavicular joint is a type of ball and socket synovial joint formed between three tarsal bones, talus, calcaneus, and navicular.
  • The convex head and plantar surface of neck of talus articulates with the socket formed by the calcaneus and navicular bones.

choices.text: Posteromedial soft tissue release
Anterolateral soft tissue release
Triple arthrodesis
Lateral closing wedge osteotomy of calcaneum

questions.text: Ponsetti technique failure in children should be managed with:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posteromedial soft tissue release

 

Option A:

 

OPERATIVE TREATMENT OF CTEV

 

  • The results of early operation, in particular neonatal surgery, have not been shown to be better than those of late surgery.
  • Delaying surgery until the child is near walking age has the advantage of operating of larger foot (making surgery easier).
  • Posteromedial soft tissue release, (Turcos) is best done at young age (1-3 years).
  • Posterior release or complete subtalar release can also be performed.

 

 

Soft tissue releases

 

  • But in children older than 3 years of age, lateral column shortening procedures are often performed in conjunction with posteromedial soft tissue release.
  • 3-8 years:
    • Soft tissue release together with shortening of lateral side of foot by Lichtblau’s Procedure (i.e. Shortening of calcaneal neck proximal to calcaneocuboid joint).
    • Preferred in <6 years of age as calcaneocuboid fusion is more difficult to achieve in this age.
    • Evan-Dillwyn Procedure (i.e. resection and fusion of calcaneocuboid joint) in 3-8 years of age (esp > 6 years) is ideal procedure.
    • Dwyer's osteotomy of calcaneum is done to correct calcaneal varus in >5 years.

 

 

Dwyer’s osteotomy to correct heel varus (>5 yrs)

 

  • 8-10 years:
    • Wedge Tarsectomy is done as deformity is more and requires multiple bones to be removed.

 

 

Wedge tarsectomy (8-10 yrs)

 

 

Triple arthrodesis (>10 yrs)

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Posterior medial release might be a single salvage procedure for treatment of clubfoot after failure of Ponseti technique.
  • It should be performed before three years of age to prevent the complications of neglected clubfoot like ulceration and osteomyelitis that might lead to amputation.

choices.text: <1 year
1-3 years
3-6 years
6-9 years

questions.text: Ideal age for PMSTR is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-3 years

 

Option B:

 

OPERATIVE TREATMENT OF CTEV

 

  • The results of early operation, in particular neonatal surgery, have not been shown to be better than those of late surgery.
  • Delaying surgery until the child is near walking age has the advantage of operating of larger foot (making surgery easier).
  • Posteromedial soft tissue release, (Turcos) is best done at young age (1-3 years).
  • Posterior release or complete subtalar release can also be performed.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Best age for posteromedial soft tissue release procedure is 1-2 years, and the upper age limit should be approximately 6 years.

choices.text: It is the same as normal shoe
It has straight medial border
It has medial shoe raise
It has heel with extra length

questions.text: True regarding CTEV shoes is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It has straight medial border

 

Option B:

 

CTEV SHOES

 

  • CTEV shoes has outer shoe raise, straight medial border and no heel it was designed by thomas.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It is the same as normal shoe. Incorrect. CTEV shoes are different from normal shoes as they do not have a heel, instead they have a flat sole.

 

Option C. It has medial shoe raise. Incorrect. Instead of a medial raise, CTEV shoes have an outer raise to prevent foot inversion and a straight medial border to prevent forefoot adduction.

 

Option D. It has heel with extra length. Incorrect. CTEV shoes do not contain any heel. This is so to prevent foot equinus.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • CTEV shoes do not have any heel and has flat sole to prevent foot equinus.
  • They have straight medial border to prevent forefoot adduction and an outer raise to prevent foot inversion.

choices.text: 1, 2
2, 3
2, 5
1, 3, 4, 5

questions.text:
True about Atypical CTEV: 

 

  1. Foot is flexed downward
  2. Sole crease are not found
  3. Difficult to treat than typical variety
  4. May occur due to neurological disorder
  5. May be associated with Meningomyelocele
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4, 5

 

Option D:

 

ATYPICAL CLUBFOOT (RESISTANT CLUBFOOT)

 

 

  • The foot is short and cylindrical.
  • The first metatarsal is often flexed and the big toe is hyperextended.
  • The foot is tight posteriorly, giving it marked equinus, but less tight medially, so there is not so much varus.
  • There is a deep transverse crease across the middle of the sole of the foot because the foot is flexed across the middle. This is called “plantaris” deformity.
  • The tibia can also appear curved
  • While typical idiopathic clubfeet respond well to the standard method of Ponseti casting and generally correct after 4-6 casts, atypical clubfeet are resistant to correction and standard manipulation and casting may lead to worsened deformity.
  • Atypical presentation of CTEV means that patients will present with not only CTEV but also with other congenital disorders, such as developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH), myelomeningocele (MMC), metatarsus adductus, and other syndromes. 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Atypical CTEV presents with foot flexed downwards.
  • It is associated with neurological disorders like meningomyelocele.
  • It is more difficult to treat than the typical type of CTEV.

choices.text: Calcaneocuboid, talonavicular and talocalcaneal
Tibiotalar, calcaneocuboid and talonavicular
Ankle joint, calcaneocuboid and talonavicular
None of the above

questions.text: In neglected cases of CTEV, joint fused are:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcaneocuboid, talonavicular and talocalcaneal

 

Option A:

 

TREATMENT OF NEGLECTED CTEV

 

  • Triple arthrodesis is necessary for recurrent or persistent clubfoot deformity in older children (chronic cases).
  • It is best done at > 10 years of age when foot growth is complete and the bones are ossified to achieve good fusion.
  • It involves fusion of three joints: TN: Talonavicular; TC: Talocalcaneal; CC: Calcaneo-Cuboid.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In neglected CTEV, calcaneocuboid, talonavicular and talocalcaneal joints are fused.

choices.text: CTEV
DDH
Genu Valgum
Hallux valgus

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common congenital anomaly in India?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CTEV

 

Option A:

 

CLUB FOOT/CONGENITAL TALIPES EQUINOVARUS (CTEV)

 

  • Club is a stick to play golf CTEV foot resembles it so called as club foot.
  • Talipes is a generic term for foot deformity that centers around the talus (Talipes = talus and pes = foot).
  • In its most characteristic form, there are usually said to be four elements of deformity i.e., equinus of ankle, inversion of foot, adduction of fore foot and medial rotation of tibia.
  • In India, the most common congenital anomaly is CTEV whereas in western countries, DDH is the commonest.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. DDH. DDH is more commonly seen in western countries.

 

Option C. Genu Valgum. It is also commonly seen in India between the age of 2-5 years. It may not be seen at birth in many children like CTEV.

 

Option D. Hallux Valgus. It is not commonly seen among children.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • CTEV is the most commonly seen congenital anomaly in India.

choices.text: Neurological disorder
Idiopathic
Spina fibida
All are correct

questions.text: CTEV is caused by:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All are correct

 

Option D:

 

ETIOLOGY OF CTEV AND ASSOCIATED ANOMALIES

 

  • Idiopathic (most common)
  • Secondary club foot:

 

1. Neurological disorders and neural tube defects, e.g. myelonieningocele and spinal dysraphism. Paralytic disorder (muscular imbalance) as polio (does not present at birth), spina bifida, myelodysplasia, and Freidreich's ataxia.

 

 

CTEV

 

2. Arthrogryposis multiplex congenita, Larsen syndrome, Sacral agenesis, tibial deficiency, constriction rings and amniotic bands.

 

3. Hip deformities are associated, e.g. DDH.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The etiology of CTEV can be neurological disorders like spina bifida or idiopathic etiology.

choices.text: Congenital talonavicular dislocation
Tightening of Tendoachilles
Calcaneal fracture
Lateral derangement

questions.text: Most important pathology in club foot is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital talonavicular dislocation

 

Option A:

 

PATHOLOGICAL ANATOMY OF CTEV

 

  • The club foot characteristically involves foot, ankle and leg.
  • Deformities of foot may be in the hind foot (ankle and subtalar joints), mid foot (mid tarsal, i.e. talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints) and forefoot.
  • Talo-calcaneo-navicular joint complex is the area involved in pathomechanics of all hind foot and mid foot deformities.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Tightening of tendoachilles. In clubfoot, the calf muscles and Achilles tendon are very tight, which limits the amount of flexibility in the ankle and pulls the heel up in the back into a non-functional position. But it is the secondary pathology that occur due to congenital foot position.

 

Option C. Calcaneal fracture. In a clubfoot, calcaneus is not fractured but it is in varus and medially rotated around the talus.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Congenital dislocation of the talonavicular is the most important pathology in club foot.

choices.text: Shortening of foot
Recurrence of deformity
Inadequate fusion
Complete correction not possible

questions.text: Triple arthrodesis is NOT done before-skeletal maturation because of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inadequate fusion

 

Option C:

 

TRIPLE ARTHRODESIS FOR CTEV

 

  • Triple arthrodesis is usually done after 10-12 years as the growth of foot is complete and the bones of foot are completely ossified.
  • Before this age, bones are not completely ossified and cartilaginous, therefore fusion (arthrodesis) may not be adequate.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Triple arthrodesis is not done before skeletal maturation because the bones are not completely ossified and this can lead to inadequate arthrodesis procedure.

choices.text: Amputation of thumb
Equalization of fingers
Toe to thumb transplantation
Reconstruction of thumb

questions.text: Pollicization is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reconstruction of thumb

 

Option D:

 

TREATMENT OF RADIAL CLUB HAND

 

  • Pollicization is transposition of finger to replace (reconstruct) absent thumb.
  • This reconstruction of thumb is usually done by migrating index finger to the position of thumb in a patient with congenital absence or marked hypoplasia of thumb.

 

 

Pollicization

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Amputation of thumb. When thumb amputation is combined with multiple digital amputations, a short thumb ceases to be functional. This is called as on-top plasty.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Pollicisation is the surgical reconstruction of the thumb by transposition of the fingers.

choices.text: Lateral condyle humerus
Supracondylar humerus
Fracture of hand
Radius-ulna fracture

questions.text: Common fractures in children are all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lateral condyle humerus

 

Options A:

 

FRACTURES IN CHILDREN

 

Order of fracture in children are:

 

  • Distal forearm (23.3%)
  • Hand (20.1%)
  • Elbow (12%) (Supracondylar humerus > Lateral Condyle Humerus)
  • Clavicle (6.4%)

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Fracture lateral condyle humerus is the least common fracture seen among the children.

choices.text: Greenstick fracture
Incremental
Torus fracture
Plastic

questions.text: All are incomplete fracture in children except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incremental

 

Option B:

 

INCREMENTAL/TODDLER’S FRACTURE

 

  • It is a fracture in ambulatory child (9 months-3 years).
  • It is spiral or oblique fracture of lower 2/3 of tibia (Undisplaced).
  • Fibula and periosteum is intact.
  • The mode of trauma is twisting injury.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Greenstick Fractures:

 

  • The cortex in tension fracture is completely broken while the cortex in compression remain intact but frequently undergo plastic deformation.

 

 

Greenstick fracture and plastic deformation

 

  • So, it is an incomplete fracture and it is necessary to complete the fracture on the intact compression side for reduction and POP application.

 

Option C. Buckle (Torus) Fracture:

 

  • It is so called, because of its resemblance to the base of an architectural column.
  • Most commonly occurs at the transition between metaphysis and diaphysis where buckling of cortex takes place.

 

 

Torus fracture

 

Option D. Plastic Deformation:

 

  • Immature bone is weaker in bending strength but absorbs more energy prior to fracture.
  • This may result in permanent deformation of bone (without fracture) known as plastic deformation.
  • It is most common in forearm particularly ulna.
  • Reduction (correction of deformity) is recommended, if there is:
    1. >20 degrees of angulation,
    2. If a child is >4 years old, and
    3. Has either a clinically evident deformity or limitation of pronation and supination

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Incremental fracture is a complete, horizontal pathological fracture seen in deformed bones in Paget’s disease.

choices.text: Metaphyseal Corner fracture
Metaphyseal bucket handle fracture
Metaphyseal fragment displacement
Subepiphyseal microfractures

questions.text: In Child abuse, all the following are X-ray feature except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subepiphyseal microfractures

 

Option D:

 

  • These are seen on MRI and not on X-rays.

 

BATTERED BABY SYNDROME/SHAKEN INFANT SYNDROME/INFANTILE WHIPLASH SYNDROME

 

  • It is a term used to define a clinical condition in young children usually under 3 years of age who have received non accidental violence or injury, on one or more occasions at the hands of an adult responsible for child's welfare.
  • This syndrome must be considered in any child: 
  1. In whom degree and type of injury is at variance with the history given.
  2. When injuries of different ages and in different stages of healing are found.
  3. When there is purposeful delay in seeking medical attention despite serious injury.
  4. Who exhibits evidence of fracture of any bone, subdural hematoma, failure to thrive, soft tissue swelling or skin bruising (ecchymosis).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Metaphyseal corner fracture and Option B. Metaphyseal bucket handle fracture. Metaphyseal corner fractures are also known as classical metaphyseal lesions (CML) or bucket handle fractures. They are observed in young children, less than 2 years old. It is suggestive of non-accidental injury. It is also common among abused children, occurring in 39-59%. There are multiple microfractures across the metaphysis in immature mineralized bone with an orientation perpendicular to the long axis of the bone. To-and-fro manipulation (shaking) is the force applied.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The X-ray in case of child abuse will not show subepiphyseal microfractures.

choices.text: Torus
Greenstick
Barton’s
Colles Fracture

questions.text: A 6-year-child is brought to emergency with complete of severe pain in aim after a fall, immediate X-ray done shows fracture distal radius and ulna. Which of the following term best describes the fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Greenstick

 

Option B:

 

GREENSTICK FRACTURES

 

  • The cortex in tension fractures completely while the cortex in compression remain intact but frequently undergo plastic deformation.

 

 

Greenstick fracture and plastic deformation

 

  • So, it is an incomplete fracture and it is necessary to complete the fracture on the intact compression side for reduction and POP application.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Torus. Buckle/Torus fracture most commonly occurs at the transition between metaphysis and diaphysis where buckling of cortex takes place.

 

 

Option C. Barton’s. It is a fracture of the distal radius which extends through the dorsal aspect of the articular surface with associated dislocation of the radiocarpal joint. There is no disruption of the radiocarpal ligaments, and the articular surface of the fractured distal radius remains in contact with the proximal carpal row.

 

 

Option D. Colles. The Colles fracture is defined as a distal radius fracture with dorsal comminution, dorsal angulation, dorsal displacement, radial shortening, and an associated ulnar styloid fracture.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A greenstick fracture is a partial thickness fracture where only the cortex and periosteum are interrupted on one side of the bone while they remain uninterrupted on the other side.

choices.text: Distal radius
Clavicle
Supracondylar humerus
Radius/ulna

questions.text: Most common bone to be fractured in children is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Radius/ulna

 

Option D:

 

FRACTURES IN CHILDREN

 

  • The immature skeleton has several unique properties that affect the management of injuries in children. These properties include thicker periosteum, soft bones, an increased resiliency to stress, an increased potential to remodel, shorter healing times, and the presence of a physis. This can lead to some characteristic fracture patterns in pediatric population.
  • Distal radius and ulna is the most common site of fracture in children accounting for nearly a quarter of fracture.
  • 2nd in frequency is Hand injury.
  • 3rd in frequency are elbow injuries. Amongst them, supracondylar fracture humerus are most common and 4th common is clavicle fracture.
  • Please remember that clavicle is the most common fractured bone in adults and during birth.
  • Dislocations and comminuted fractures are rare in children.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common bone to be fractured in children is the radius/ulna.

choices.text: Humerus
Proximal ulna
Distal radius
Carpals

questions.text: Madelung’s deformity involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Distal radius

 

Option C:

 

MADELUNG’S DEFORMITY

 

  • Madelung deformity is seen in patients with Turner syndrome.

 

 

 

  • Distal radius joint surface is inclined anteriorly and towards ulna.
  • There is deficiency of volar and ulnar part of distal radius.
  • The ulnar head becomes prominent.
  • The deformity is more common in females and is often bilateral.
  • The functions are good and usually don't require intervention.
  • In case there is a requirement, radial osteotomy and excision of ulnar head can be done.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Madelung deformity includes fracture of the distal radius.

choices.text: Antibiotics and sedative
Bone plating and external fixation
Slab with wait for bone imperfect
Break the other side of cortex and immobilization by POP

questions.text: A 6-year-old child falls in right-sided forearm region and develops fracture in dorsal surface of mid region of radius. The best treatment is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Break the other side of cortex and immobilization by POP

 

Option D:

 

GREENSTICK FRACTURES

 

  • The cortex in tension fractures completely while the cortex in compression remain intact but frequently undergo plastic deformation.

 

 

Greenstick fracture and plastic deformation

 

  • So, it is an incomplete fracture and it is necessary to complete the fracture on the intact compression side for reduction and POP application.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Most greenstick fractures are treated with a cast. This helps not only to keep the bones in place as they heal, but also to prevent further breakage of the already damaged bone.

choices.text: Angulation in diaphysis
Angulation in metaphysis
Rotation in diaphysis
Rotation in metaphysis

questions.text: In children, best remodeling is seen in fracture with:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Angulation in metaphysis

 

Option B:

 

REMODELING POTENTIAL IN CHILDREN

 

  • Bone remodeling is a gradual process.
  • In children, metaphyseal fractures are more common.
  • The growth plates located near the metaphysis are responsible for bone elongation and can help with the remodeling process.
  • As the child grows, remodeling corrects the angulation gradually.
  • According to the Wolff’s Law, the bone adapts to the mechanical forces imposed on it.
  • The forces acting on the bone during weight-bearing and movement stimulate the osteoblasts which increases the bone formation.
  • Also, in angulated fractures, the osteoclasts are stimulated to remove excess bone at the site of the fracture.
  • These factors combined together contribute to the best remodeling outcome in fractures with angulation of metaphysis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Angulation in diaphysis. Roughly 20% of angular remodeling occurs in the diaphysis. Remodeling in the diaphysis follows Wolf's law i.e., increased pressure (compression) on the concave side stimulates new bone formation. Tension on the convex side leads to resorption of bone.

 

Option C. Rotation in diaphysis and Option D. Rotation in metaphysis. For practical purposes, no rotational remodeling occurs.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In children, the best remodeling is seen in fractures with angulation of the metaphysis.

Ans. B) Type II

EPIPHYSEAL INJURY

 

  • In type II of Salter Harris classification of epiphyseal injury, the fracture line extends from physis into the Metaphysis. This is called Thurston-Holland’s fragment sign.

choices.text: Seen around foramen magnum
Seen around epiphyseal plate
More prominent in adults
Shear strength increases with age

questions.text: Perichondrial ring is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Seen around epiphyseal plate

 

Option B:

 

EPIPHYSEAL INJURY

 

  • The perichondrial ring surrounds the growth plate circumferentially, similar to perichondrial groove.
  • Perichondrial ring extends towards metaphysis and become continuous with periosteum of metaphysis.
  • With increasing age, perichondrial ring is thinned and its shear resistance (strength) is decreased.
  • Rang's type VI is Injury to Perichondrial ring.
  • Peterson type I fracture is a transverse fracture of metaphysis with extension longitudinally into the physis (commonly seen in distal radius).
  • Paterson type VI injury is an open injury associated with loss of physis.

choices.text: Transverse fracture of metaphysis with longitudinal extension into physis
Open injury with loss of physis
Thurston Holland's sign
Perichondrial ring injury

questions.text: Type VI Rang’s injury includes:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Perichondrial ring injury

 

Option D:

 

EPIPHYSEAL INJURY

 

  • Rang’s type VI is perichondrial ring injury.
  • The perichondrial ring surrounds the growth plate circumferentially, similar to perichondrial groove.
  • Perichondrial ring extends towards metaphysis and become continuous with periosteum of metaphysis.
  • With increasing age, perichondrial ring is thinned and its shear resistance (strength) is decreased.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Transverse fracture of metaphysis with longitudinal extension into physis. Peterson type I fracture is a transverse fracture of metaphysis with longitudinal extension into the physis. It is commonly seen in distal radius.

 

Option B. Open injury with loss of physis. Paterson type VI injury is an open injury associated with loss of physis.

 

Option C. Thurston Holland’s sign. Type II of Salter-Harris classification for epiphyseal injury represent Thurston Holland’s sign in which the fracture extends from the physis into the metaphysis.  

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Type VI Rang’s injury includes perichondrial ring injury which extends towards metaphysis and becomes continuous with its periosteum.

choices.text: Undiagnosed malunited fracture
Avascular necrosis talus
Tibial epiphyseal injury
Ligamentous injury of ankle joint

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with a history of fall from 10 feet height complains of pain in the right ankle. X-ray taken at that time are normal without any fracture line. But after 2 years, he developed a calcaneovalgus deformity. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tibial epiphyseal injury

 

Option C:

 

EPIPHYSEAL INJURY

 

  • Epiphyseal injuries can have normal X-rays as cartilage is not seen on X-rays and there can be deformities subsequently due to damage to growth plate.
  • Epiphyseal fractures are more common than ligamentous injuries in children since the ligaments of the joints are generally stronger than their associated growth plates.
  • Fractures across the growth plate may produce bony bridges that will cause premature cessation of growth or angular deformities of the extremity.
  • These bridges are due to the trauma to the growth plate and can occur even with adequate reductions. 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tibial epiphyseal injury may appear normal on x-rays but can lead to deformities over time if left untreated.

choices.text: Hyperparathyroidism
Hypoparathyroidism
Hypothyroidism
Hyperthyroidism

questions.text: Epiphyseal dysgenesis is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypothyroidism

 

Option C:

 

EPIPHYSEAL APPEARANCE ON RADIOLOGY FOR DIAGNOSIS

 

  • Epiphyseal Enlargement:
    • Most common causes of epiphyseal enlargement are chronic inflammation (e.g. JRA) due to chronic increase in blood flow.
    • Causes of Epiphyseal enlargement are:

a. Solitary:

  1. Post inflammatory (JRA, Septic arthritis)
  2. Perthes disease (in repair stage)
  3. Hemophilia (Hemophilic arthropathy)
  4. Turner syndrome
  5. Trevor disease (Dysplasia epiphysealis hemimelica)

b. Generalized:

  1. Hyperthyroidism
  2. Acromegaly or cerebral gigantism
  3. Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia
  4. Rickets
  5. McCune-Albright syndrome
  • Thyroid hormone is responsible for proliferation and maturation of chondrocytes.
  • Functions of Thyroid hormone in bone formation are:
    • Maturation and ossification of the epiphyseal plates
    • Proliferation and maturation of chondrocytes
    • Endochondral ossification
    • Bone metabolism
  • Deficiency of thyroid hormone impairs the bone regulation.
  • It leads to delayed epiphyseal maturation, inadequate and impaired cartilage to bone conversion and altered bone metabolism.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hyperparathyroidism. Primary hyperparathyroidism is not commonly seen in children and adolescents.

 

Option B. Hypoparathyroidism.  Hypoparathyroidism is a rare disorder that may be acquired or inherited. Bone disease occurs in hypoparathyroidism due to markedly reduced bone remodelling due to the absence or low levels of parathyroid hormone.

 

Option D. Hyperthyroidism.  Thyrotoxicosis in children is relatively rare and causes accelerated intramembranous and endochondral ossification and an increase in linear growth rate. Paradoxically, this may result in premature fusion of the growth plates and early cessation of growth leading to persistent short stature. In severe thyrotoxicosis in young children, early closure of the cranial sutures can result in craniosynostosis with neurological sequelae. Untreated hyperthyroidism during pregnancy is also associated with craniosynostosis and may be a causative risk factor.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Epipyseal dysgenesis/Fragmented/punctate epiphysis is due to Hypothyroidism.

choices.text: It is an autosomal recessive disease
It is an epiphyseal dysplasia
Mental retardation is uncommon
Dental caries and mandibular prognathism

questions.text: All of the following are features of Pyle disease except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is an epiphyseal dysplasia

 

Option B:

 

METAPHYSEAL DYSPLASIA (PYLE’S DISEASE)

 

  • A.R
  • Mental retardation (intellectual disability)
  • Genu Valgum
  • Widening of Bones (e.g. Femur)
  • Dental carries, Mandibular prognathism

 

EPIPHYSEAL APPEARANCE ON RADIOLOGY FOR DIAGNOSIS

 

Epiphyseal Enlargement:

 

  • Most common causes of epiphyseal enlargement are chronic inflammation (e.g. JRA) due to chronic increase in blood flow.
  • Causes of Epiphyseal enlargement are:
  1. Solitary:
  1. Post inflammatory (JRA, Septic arthritis)
  2. Perthes disease (in repair stage)
  3. Hemophilia (Hemophilic arthropathy)
  4. Turner syndrome
  5. Trevor disease (Dysplasia epiphysealis hemimelica)
  1. Generalized:
  1. Hyperthyroidism
  2. Acromegaly or cerebral gigantism
  3. Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia
  4. Rickets
  5. McCune-Albright syndrome
  6. Epipyseal dysgenesis/Fragmented/punctate epiphysis Hypothyroidism.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • It is an autosomal recessive disease.
  • The hallmark feature of Pyle disease is that the metaphysis of the long bones of the arms and legs are abnormally broad, and the shape of bones resembles a boat paddle.
  • Broad metaphyses are due to enlargement of the trabeculae of the bone while the cortical part becomes thinner than normal.
  • As a result, the bones become fragile and fracture easily.
  • The bony deformity commonly seen in such cases is genu valgum.  
  • Mental retardation is uncommon.
  • There is presence of dental caries and mandibular prognathism.

choices.text: Congenital scoliosis
Dextrocardia
Diastematomyelia
Klippel-Feil syndrome

questions.text: Sprengel’s deformity is associated with all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dextrocardia

 

Option B:

 

CONGENITAL HIGH SCAPULA (SPRENGEL’S DEFORMITY)

 

  • It consists of permanent elevation of the shoulder girdle due to developmental defect.
  • The scapula is smaller in its vertical diameter and appears broad. It lies high in position.
  • Para scapular muscles are composed of imperfectly developed muscle fibers or fibrous tissue.
  • From the superior angle of Scapula, a sheet or band-like structure composed of fibrous tissue cartilage or bone extends upwards to attach to the transverse process of several cervical vertebrae known as Omovertebral bar.

 

 

Sprengel Shoulder

 

  • C/F: Shoulder and the scapula at a higher level than the opposite one, Restriction of shoulder movement.
  • Treatment: There is no definitive treatment available. Surgery (Woodward procedure) is done for cosmetic reasons only.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Congenital scoliosis, Option C. Diastematomyelia (congenital splitting of spinal cord at the level of upper lumbar vertebra), and Option D. Klippel-Feil syndrome (abnormal fusion of 2 or more bones in cervical spine) are the features associated with Sprengel’s deformity.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Sprengel’s deformity is not associated with dextrocardia, instead it is associated with congenital scoliosis, diastematomyelia and Klippel-Feil syndrome.

choices.text: Short neck
Low hair line
Limited neck movements
Elevated scapula

questions.text: The characteristic triad of Klippel-Feil syndrome includes all the following, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Elevated scapula

 

Option D:

 

KLIPPEL-FEIL SYNDROME

 

  • High riding Scapula (Sprengel deformity) may be associated with Klippel-Feil syndrome, but does not form part of the characteristic triad.
  • The characteristic triad of Klippel-Feil syndrome includes a short neck, low hair line and restriction of neck motion.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Characteristic triad of Klippel-Feil syndrome does not include elevated scapula, instead the triad consists of short neck, low hair line and restricted neck movements.

choices.text: Low hair line
Bilateral Neck webbing
Bilateral shortness of sternomastoid muscles
Gross limitations of neck movements

questions.text: In Klippel-Feil syndrome, the patient has all of the following clinical features except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bilateral shortness of sternomastoid muscles

 

Option C:

 

KLIPPEL-FEIL SYNDROME

 

  • Klippel-Feil Syndrome is congenital fusion of one or more cervical vertebrae presenting with classical triad of low hair line, short ‘web' neck (prominence of trapezius muscle), and limited neck motion seen in 50% cases.

 

 

  • Abnormal head position, true torticollis, and restricted range of motion, without an obvious SCM (sternocleidomastoid) contracture, is an indication for X-rays of cervical spine for evidence of cervical fusion.
  • It is associated with congenital osseous fusions (synostosis) and failure of segmentation of the cervical spine, involving two or more vertebrae.
  • Such fusions can involve the craniocervical junction (occiput to C2), the subaxial cervical spine or both; and results from a failure of the normal division of the cervical somites during the 3rd to 8th week of embryogenesis.
  • Associated Features:
    • Musculoskeletal System:
      • Scoliosis (~60%) due to fusion of cervical and cervicothoracic junction.
      • Sprengel's deformity (~50%) – It is congenitally elevated or undescended scapula.
      • (Omovertebral bone bridges the cervical spine to the scapula and limits the neck and shoulder motion.)
      • Webbing of neck, facial asymmetry and torticollis.
      • Radiographic findings of congenital cervical vertebral fusion are diagnostic.
      • Neurological sequelae due to involvement of brain stem or cervical cord may be present.
      • Syndactyly and diffuse or focal upper extremity hypoplasia.
      • Secondary osteoarthritis, disc degeneration, spinal stenosis.
  • Other Findings:
    • Genito renal anomalies (~35%, so USG is recommended)
    • Congenital heart defects (~15%, so ECHO is recommended)

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Bilateral shortness of sternomastoid muscles is not seen in Klippel-Feil syndrome.
  • Klippel-Feil syndrome is characterized by low hair line, bilateral webbing of neck and gross restriction of neck movements.

choices.text: It is present at upper 2/3rd and lower 1/3rd junction of SCM
It is always present at birth
It is associated with oligohydramnios and limb defects
It undergoes spontaneous resolution

questions.text: Not true about sternocleidomastoid (SCM) tumour:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is always present at birth

 

Option B:

 

CONGENITAL (INFANTILE) MUSCULAR TORTICOLLIS OR WRY NECK

 

 

  • Torticollis or twisted neck is a symptom of cervical spine abnormality.
  • It may be of two types: congenital and secondary.
  • Congenital or infantile torticollis is commonest form of wry neck.
  • It is due to fibrosis of sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle on one side that fails to elongate as child grows.
  • The cause is muscle ischemia from a distorted position in utero (breech) or birth injury.
  • A history of difficult labor followed by lump over SCM (sternocleidomastoid tumor) in first few weeks of life, which disappears in few months is present. Then, there is neither deformity nor obvious limitation of movements.
  • Deformity does not become apparent until the child is 1-2 years old.
  • It is associated with breech delivery, shoulder dystocia, birth injury and SCM ischemia/tumor.
  • The head is tilted toward the involved SCM and the chin is rotated towards the contralateral shoulder, producing the ‘Cock robin' appearance.
  • SCM on involved side may feel tight and hard and a mass or knot can be detected in the body of SCM in first 3 months of life.
  • It can disappear spontaneously.
  • There may be asymmetrical development of face (plagiocephaly).
  • Treatment: Unipolar (one head of SCM) or bipolar (two heads of SCM) release, Optimum age: 1-4 years.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • SCM tumor is present at the upper 2/3rd and lower 1/3rd junction of SCM.
  • It is associated with oligohydramnios & limb defects.
  • It resolves spontaneously.

CONGENITAL (INFANTILE) MUSCULAR TORTICOLLIS OR WRY NECK

  • Deformity does not become apparent until the child is 1-2 years old.
  • It is associated with breech delivery, shoulder dystocia, birth injury and SCM ischemia/tumor.
  • The head is tilted toward the involved SCM and the chin is rotated towards the contralateral shoulder, producing the ‘Cock robin' appearance.
  • SCM on involved side may feel tight and hard and a mass or knot can be detected in the body of SCM in first 3 months of life.
  • It can disappear spontaneously.
  • There may be asymmetrical development of face (plagiocephaly).
  • Treatment: Unipolar (one head of SCM) or bipolar (two heads of SCM) release, Optimum age: 1-4 years.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Congenital torticollis, also known as sternocleidomastoid (SCM) tumor, is the fibrosis of SCM muscle on one side that fails to elongate as the child grows.

CONGENITAL (INFANTILE) MUSCULAR TORTICOLLIS OR WRY NECK
