  • A history of difficult labour followed by lump over SCM (sternomastoid tumor) in first few weeks of life, which disappears in few months is present. Then, there is neither deformity nor obvious limitation of movements.
  • Deformity does not become apparent until the child is 1-2 years old.

  • The head is tilted toward the involved SCM and the chin is rotated towards the contralateral shoulder, producing the ‘Cock robin' appearance.

Trauma disease
Malignancy
All are correct

questions.text: Vertebra plana seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All are correct

 

Option D:

 

VERTEBRA PLANA

 

 

  • Vertebra plana is collapse and increased density of one vertebral body, with normal or increased disc space.
  • Causes are Eosinophilic granuloma (histiocytosis), Ewings's sarcoma, metastasis, leukemia, tuberculosis (very rare) and Calves' disease (osteochondritis of vertebral body).

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Vertebra plana is seen in eosinophilic granuloma, trauma, and malignancy.

choices.text: Minerva cast
Milwaukee brace
Crutchfield traction
PTB cast

questions.text: Idiopathic scoliosis can be treated by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Milwaukee brace

 

Option B:

 

TREATMENT OF SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Brace treatment is restricted to immature children in an attempt to prevent curve progression during further skeletal growth.
  • So, it is indicated in Growing adolescents (Risser 0, 1 or 2) who, on presentation, have curves in range of 30-45 degrees or who have had documented progression exceeding 5 degrees in curve that initially measured 20-30 degrees.
  • TLSOs are the most commonly used orthoses today, but their use is restricted to patients whose curve apex is at or below T7.
  • Fortunately, this is the case in most idiopathic scoliosis.
  • These patient should have deformities that are considered cosmetically acceptable.
  • Patient should be realistically willing to wear the brace the prescribed amount of time.
  • Contraindication:
    • Large curves (>45 degrees) in growing adolescents (need surgical treatment). However, there is an exception to this rule. Very immature adolescents who have not yet reached their peak height velocity and who have large curves (~50º) may benefit from brace in an effort to delay progression until maturity is reached.
    • Extreme thoracic hypokyphosis (as normal positioning of pads could exacerbate rib deformity).
    • Skeletally mature adolescent (Riser 4 or 5, and in females, 2 years post-menarchial).
    • High thoracic or cervico-thoracic curve (relative contraindication).

 

 

 

Milwaukee brace

  • Treatment Plan of Idiopathic Scoliosis:

 

 

  • Suspensory plaster cast of sayre, Rissers cast hinge or turnbuckle cast of Hibbs and Kisser, Milwaukee brace, Boston brace, Charleston night-time bending brace, Wilmington brace and thoraco-lumbo- sacral orthoses (TLSOs) are used to treat idiopathic scoliosis (Lower Dorsal scoliosis > Lumbar Scoliosis).
  • Surgical treatment consists of corrective osteotomies and fusion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Minerva cast. A minerva cast is a special type of cast that can be used to treat certain types of scoliosis and cervical spine fractures. It extends along the side and in back of the head and neck, chest to hip area, and incorporates a plaster-of-Paris headband.

 

 

 

Option C. Crutchfield traction. It is a traction device whose pins are inserted into the skull to distract and/or immobilize the neck. Crutchfield tongs are used to stabilize fractures of the cervical spine.

 

 

Option D. PTB cast. The PTB or patellar tendon bearing cast is used to treat fractures of the Tibia, usually the mid to distal third fractures.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Idiopathic scoliosis is best treated with the use of a Milwaukee brace to prevent progression of the curve during skeletal growth.

choices.text: Kyphoscoliosis
Angular deformity of the knee
Extent of depression in calcaneal fracture
Extent of spondylolisthesis

questions.text: Cobb’s angle is used to measure the degree of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kyphoscoliosis

 

Option A:

 

COBB’S ANGLE

 

 

Cobb’s angle

 

  • The Cobb angle is the most widely used measurement to quantify the magnitude of spinal deformities, in the case of scoliosis, on plain radiographs.
  • Scoliosis is defined as a lateral spinal curvature with a Cobb angle of >10°.
  • A Cobb angle can also aid kyphosis or lordosis assessment in the sagittal plane.
  • Measurement:
    • To measure the Cobb angle, one must first decide which vertebrae are the end vertebrae of the curve deformity (the terminal vertebrae) – the vertebra whose endplates are most tilted towards each other. 
    • Lines are then drawn along the endplates (or the pedicles if the endplates are not properly visualized), and the angle between the two lines, where they intersect, measured. 
    • In cases where the curvature is not marked, then the lines will not intersect on the film/monitor, in which case a further two lines can be plotted, each at right angles to the previous lines.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Angular deformity of the knee. The angulation in the knees are measured using the radiographic scannogram of the lower extremity.

 

 

Option C. Extent of depression in calcaneal fracture. It is measured by Bohler's Angle, that may be depressed on plain radiographs. It is defined as the angle between two lines drawn on plain film. The first line is between the highest point on the tuberosity and the highest point of posterior facet and the second is the highest point on the anterior process and the highest point on the posterior facet. The normal angle is between 20-40 degrees. 

 

 

Option D. Extent of spondylolisthesis. The Meyerding classification grade is used to measure the degree of slip using standing, neutral lateral radiographs of the lumbar spine. The classification system divides slip into five grades (shown in table below). The grade percent is determined by drawing a line through the posterior wall of the superior and inferior vertebral bodies and measuring the translation of the superior vertebral body as a percentage of the distance between the two lines. Grades I and II are generally considered low-grade slip, whereas Grades III, IV, and V are considered high-grade slip. Grade V is also called spondyloptosis.

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The Cobb angle is utilized to assess for severity of kyphoscoliosis, risk of progression, and means of intervention.

choices.text: Forward bending
Backward bending
Sideways
Without bending

questions.text: Vertebral rotation in scoliosis is checked in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Forward bending

 

Option A:

 

TEST FOR SCOLIOSIS

 

  • This is called Adam’s test.

 

 

  • Adam test is done to differentiate between Postural Vs Structural Scoliosis.
  • If the curvature corrects itself on forward bending, it is Postural Scoliosis.
  • Structural curve becomes more prominent on forward bending.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Vertebral rotation in scoliosis is checked by forward bending test called Adam’s test.

choices.text: Fully segmented hemivertebra
Wedge vertebra
Block vertebra
Unilateral unsegmented bar with Hemivertebra

questions.text: Progression of congenital scoliosis is least likely in which of the following vertebra anomalies?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Block vertebra

 

Option C:

 

CONGENITAL SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Unsegmented bar with hemivertebra > unsegmented bar > hemivertebra > wedge vertebra > block vertebra.
  • Unsegmented bar with hemivertebra: This carries the worst prognosis and greatest risk of progression (5-10 degrees per year).
  • Block Vertebra: This carries the best prognosis and lowest risk of progression (Stable or minimal progression) (<1 degree to 1 degree per year).

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fully segmented hemivertebra is the second vertebral anomaly that most likely has the chance of progression of congenital scoliosis.

 

Option B. Wedge vertebra. The characteristic radiographic deformity of congenital scoliosis is represented by lateral bending in the coronal plane, along with different degrees of vertebral wedge change. Even a slight scoliosis deformity is marked by this kind of change, which worsens with curve progression.

 

Option D. Unilateral unsegmented bar with hemivertebra. It has the greatest potential for rapid progression (5 to 10 degrees/year).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Out of all the vertebral anomalies, block vertebra has the least chance of progression (< 2 degrees/year).

choices.text: Hypertrophy of limb
Scoliosis
Pseudo arthrosis
All of the above

questions.text: Musculoskeletal abnormalities in neurofibromatosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

MUSCULOSKELETAL ABNORMALITIES IN NEUROFIBROMATOSIS

 

  • Pseudoarthrosis of tibia
  • Short stature
  • Scoliosis (Most common)
  • Limb hypertrophy due to multiple neurofibromas
  • Distinctive osseous lesion: sphenoid dysplasia or cortical thinning of long bones

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Musculoskeletal abnormalities commonly seen in neurofibromatosis are hypertrophy of limb, scoliosis and pseudoarthrosis.

choices.text: Optic glioma
Dumbbell neurofibroma
Scoliosis
Periventricular calcifications

questions.text: The common features of Neurofibromatosis include all, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Periventricular calcifications

 

Option D:

 

NEUROFIBROMATOSIS (NF)

 

  • It is hereditary, hamartomatous disorder, that affects central and peripheral nervous system, skeletal, skin and deeper soft tissue.
  • It is one of the commonest single gene disorder affecting the skeletal system.

 

NF – 1/VON RECKLINGHAUSEN’S DISEASE

 

  • Most common single gene disorder affecting human nervous system.
  • Also called as peripheral neurofibromatosis, is due to defect in chromosome 17.
  • AD inheritance, and 50% patients result from new mutation.
  • 100% penetrance, i.e. individual with abnormal chromosome 17 will show same clinical feature.
  • Clinical presentation includes cafe au lait spots (most common feature) axillary, and inguinal freckling (2nd MC), cutaneous neurofibromas, plexiform neurofibromas (~5% are premalignant), Lisch nodule on iris, veruccous hyperplasia (thickened overgrown valvety soft skin), elephantiasis (pachydermatocele), optic glioma, skeletal abnormalities (scoliosis, congenital pseudoarthrosis of tibia, hemihypertrophy) and cognitive deficits (learning disability).
  • Complications include epilepsy, hydrocephalus, cognitive deficits, intracranial tumor, optic glioma, short stature, precocious puberty, hypothalamic dysfunction, renal artery stenosis and hypertension.
  • Diagnostic criteria for NF-1 are met if Two or More criteria are found:
  • > 6 cafe au-lait spots, at least 15 mm in greatest diameter inadults and 5 mm in children
  • Neurofibromas of any type or one plexiform neurofibroma
  • Axillary or inguinal freckling (crowe's sign)
  • Lisch nodule (iris hamartomas)
  • Optic glioma
  • Musculoskeletal lesion such as scoliosis, sphenoid dysplasia, or thinning of cortex of long bone, with or without pseudoarthrosis.
  • A first degree relative (parent, sibling, or offspring) with NF-1 by above criteria.

 

NF – 2

 

  • Also known as central neurofibromatosis or bilateral acoustic neurofibromatosis and is due to defect in long arm of chromosome 22.
  • Less common type, AD inheritance, and 50% cases are due to new mutation.
  • Musculoskeletal deformities encountered in NF-1 are generally absent in NF-2.
  • 8th nerve vestibular schwannomas occur in nearly every individual with NF-2 (not seen in NF-1).
  • Meningioma occur in 50% cases.
  • Diagnostic criteria for NF-2 are met if a person has either of the following:
  • Bilateral 8th nerve masses seen on MRI
  • A first degree relative with NF2 and either a unilateral 8th nerve mass or two of the following
  • Neurofibroma
  • Meningioma
  • Glioma
  • Schwannoma
  • Juvenile posterior subscapsular lenticular opacity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Optic glioma (can affect the optic nerve or optic chiasma), Option B. Dumbbell neurofibroma (dumbbell-shaped thoracic neurofibroma in the spinal canal & posterior thoracic cavity), and Option C. Scoliosis are all features seen in neurofibromatosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Periventricular calcifications are seen in congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection in the brain.
  • These calcifications have an asymmetric focus.

choices.text: Tibial Hemimelia
Fibula Hemimelia
Congenital pseudarthrosis of Tibia
Congenital posteromedial angulation of Tibia

questions.text: The following deformity is seen in a child. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Congenital pseudarthrosis of Tibia

 

Option C:

 

PSEUARTHROSIS

 

  • It is a false joint that may develop after a fracture that has not united properly due to inadequate immobilization.
  • If a nonunion allows for too much motion along the fracture gap, the central portion of the callus undergoes cystic degeneration and the luminal surface can actually become lined by synovial like cells, creating a false joint filled with clear fluid known as pseudarthrosis.
  • Most Common Cause of Pseudarthrosis: Idiopathic > Neurofibromatosis (NF-1) (Actually an association, not a cause)
  • Causes of Pseudarthrosis are:
    1. Neurofibromatosis (50% patients of pseudarthrosis have NF)
    2. Nonunion of fracture (including pathological fractures)
    3. Congenital (mostly in lower to middle third of tibia with cupping of proximal bone end and pointing of distal bone end)
    4. Osteogenesis imperfecta
    5. Fibrous dysplasia
    6. Cleidocranial dysplasia
    7. Ankylosing spondylitis (in fused bamboo spine)
    8. Post-surgical, e.g. Triple arthrodesis, spinal fusion as a complication
  • Tibia is most commonly involved bone.
  • Five forms of congenital pseudarthosis of tibia are dysplastic, cystic, sclerotic, fibular and clubfoot or congenital band type.
  • The most common dysplastic type is tapered at defective site; an hour glass Constriction. It is associated with neurofibromatosis.
  • Poor fracture healing and recurrent fracture is common even if union is achieved.
  • Cast immobilization is generally unsuccessful.
  • Initial treatment is nailing and bone grafting or Ilizarov fixator.
  • Vascularized Fibular graft is done if multiple failed surgeries.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tibial hemimelia. Tibial hemimelia (TH) manifests as a shortened leg with knee and ankle deformities. Most often seen deformities are varus in the ankle and a knee flexion contracture in the knee.

 

 

Option B. Fibula hemimelia. Children who have fibular hemimelia are born with a short or missing fibula. Other bones in the leg, ankle, and foot can be affected too. Most children with fibular hemimelia have it in one leg, but some have it in both.

 

 

Option D. Congenital posteromedial angulation of tibia. Posteromedial bowing of tibia is a congenital condition often associated with calcaneovalgus deformity of ipsilateral foot. This condition undergoes spontaneous resolution to a major extent, often leaving only leg length inequality. The latter may result in abnormal gait and backache.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Congenital pseudarthrosis of the tibia is a rare dysplastic pathological condition of the lower limbs, associated with neurofibromatosis type 1.
  • It may be seen at birth or manifest at the walking age with pathological fractures leading to deformity and limb length discrepancy.

choices.text: Intrauterine fracture
Neurofibromatosis
Fibrous dysplasia
Unknown

questions.text: Cause of congenital pseudarthrosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Unknown

 

Option D:

 

CONGENITAL PSEUDARTHROSIS

 

  • Neurofibromatosis is an association; it is not a cause.
  • Causes of Pseudarthrosis are:
    • Neurofibromatosis (50% patients of pseudarthrosis have NF)
    • Nonunion of fracture (including pathological fractures)
    • Congenital (mostly in lower to middle third of tibia with cupping of proximal bone end and pointing of distal bone end)
    • Osteogenesis imperfecta
    • Fibrous dysplasia
    • Cleidocranial dysplasia
    • Ankylosing spondylitis (in fused bamboo spine)
    • Post-surgical, e.g. Triple arthrodesis, spinal fusion as a complication.
      • Tibia is most commonly involved bone.
      • Five forms of congenital pseudarthosis of tibia are: dysplastic, cystic, sclerotic, fibular and clubfoot or congenital band type.
      • The most common dysplastic type is tapered at defective site; an hour glass Constriction, it is associated with neurofibromatosis.
      • Poor fracture healing and recurrent fracture is common even if union is achieved.
      • Cast immobilization is generally unsuccessful.
      • Initial treatment is nailing and bone grafting or Ilizarov fixator.
      • Vascularized Fibular graft is done if multiple failed surgeries.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Neurofibromatosis. Neurofibromatosis is an association; it is not a cause.

 

Option C. Fibrous dysplasia. Pseudarthrosis is associated with fibrous dysplasia and not caused by it.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common cause of congenital pseudarthrosis is idiopathic (unknown).

choices.text: Dystrophy
Neuropathy
Metaphyseal dysplasia
NF

questions.text: The child with the following clinical presentation will most probably have the underlying diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dystrophy

 

Option A:

 

DUCHENNE MUSCULAR DYSTROPHY

  •  
  • X-linked Recessive (Xp 21)
  • Dystrophin gene mutation is seen
  • Boys (more common)
  • Average age of presentation is 4 years
  • Patient is Unable to walk by 12 years of age
  • Average life span is 26 years
  • Proximal muscle weakness is seen
  • Contractures of Achilles and Hamstring is seen
  • Pseudohypertrophy of calf and tongue is seen
  • Gait: patient is usually a toe walker
  • There is increase in Lumbar Lordosis
  • Scoliosis is seen
  • Gower's sign (patient climbs on himself)

 

 

Gower’s sign

 

  • Cardiomyopathy and congestive heart failure is seen
  • There is increase in Creatine Kinase and EMG shows Muscle damage.
  • Definitive diagnosis is by muscle biopsy and genetic testing.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Neuropathy. The main symptoms can include:

 

  • Numbness and tingling in the feet
  • Burning, stabbing or shooting pain in affected areas
  • Loss of balance and co-ordination
  • Muscle weakness, especially in the feet

 

Option C. Metaphyseal dysplasia. It is characterized by progressive short stature that develops by age of two years. The clinical and radiographic features are usually not present at birth, but manifest in early childhood with short limbs, genu varum, and waddling gait.

 

Option D. Neurofibromatosis (NF). The skeletal abnormalities seen in neurofibromatosis includes scoliosis, congenital pseudoarthrosis of tibia, and hemihypertrophy. 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Muscular dystrophy presents with pseudohypertrophy of the calf muscles, which is the main differentiating sign seen in such patients.

choices.text: Fibrillin-1 gene
FGFR-3 gene
COL1A-1 gene
Fibrillin-2 gene

questions.text: Mutation seen in Marfan syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibrilliin-1 gene

 

Option A:

 

MARFAN SYNDROME: FIBRILLIN 1 DEFECT

 

  • There is increase in the height (Disproportionate)
  • The limbs are long and there is arachnodactyly (fingers and hand are long and have spider like appearance)
  • Scoliosis is seen
  • Pectus excavatum/Pectus carinatum
  • Hyperlaxity
  • High-arched palate
  • Pes planus
  • Hammer toes
  • Early OA is a feature
  • Ghent criterion is used for diagnosis of Marfan syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. FGFR-3 gene. Activating mutations in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3) gene are responsible for several autosomal dominant craniosynostosis syndromes and chondrodysplasias i.e. hypochondroplasia, achondroplasia, and thanatophoric dysplasia – a neonatal lethal dwarfism syndrome.

 

Option C. COL1A-1 gene. Mutations of COL1A1 gene is associated with osteogenesis imperfecta, some types of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Caffey diseases, and osteogenesis imperfect/Ehlers- Danlos syndrome overlapping diseases.

 

Option D. Fibrillin-2 gene. Mutations in the gene for fibrillin-2 cause Congenital Contractural Arachnodactyly.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Mutations in the gene for fibrillin-1 cause the Marfan syndrome.
